editionStmt.p: The initial version of this file was created from data kindly provided by the Ethiopic Manuscript Imaging Project directed by Steve Delamarter.

publicationStmt.publisher: Die Schriftkultur des christlichen Äthiopiens und Eritreas: Eine multimediale Forschungsumgebung / Beta maṣāḥǝft

licence.p: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0.

msContents.summary: F-165v: Psalter, ዳዊት፡. Hiob Ludolf, Psalterium Davidis Aethiopice et Latine, 1701. Printed several times in Ethiopia, e. g. MD. F-129r: 151 Psalms of David. The word for God is rubricated throughout. Marginal numbers indicate Qalu reckoning by 10's. The midpoint of the Psalms () is marked with the line written in alternating red and black ink. Psalm 151 is written in columetric layout with red letters in the first, third, and fifth positions. Psalm 151 is the long version. F-141v: Fifteen Biblical Canticles. The fourth canticle is Song of Hana, mother of Samuel, prophet. -149v: Song of Songs, in the Hebraic or Scholars' Edition. F-160v: Praises of Mary, arranged for the days of the week, beginning with prayers for Monday. F-165v: Gate of Light. F-xx: Angels Praise Her, written in a different and later hand. Notes: F. i v(erso), top: Excerpt from the Pslams, written in an untrained hand. F. i v(erso), bottom: Asmat prayer against colic, ሕማመ፡ ቁርፀት፡. F. ii r(ecto) and v(erso): excerpt from Absolution of the Son, written in a different hand. F. iii r(ecto): excerpt from Psalm 140, written in the same hand as the base hand of the book. F. iii v(erso): Record: Note of ownership, This book belongs to Abuna ወልደ ሥላሴ who bought it with his own money to save his soul and body. Other members of his family are mentioned. : Record: A record of the ownership of a plot of land, in Old Amharic. Illuminations: i v(erso): crude drawing of horse and rider with spear. F. ii r(ecto): Crude drawing in purple ink of horse and rider. F. ii v(erso): Angel with sword and scabbard. Both the front and back inside covers appear to have mirror niches with a residue of glue. Sheguala Maryam
